title: ICE combining specialization with associated constants as array lengths

labels.name: I-ICE
labels.description: Issue: The compiler panicked, giving an Internal Compilation Error (ICE) ❄️

labels.name: E-needs-test
labels.description: Call for participation: writing correctness tests

labels.name: A-associated-items
labels.description: Area: Associated items such as associated types and consts.

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: requires-nightly
labels.description: This issue requires a nightly compiler in some way.

body:
Testcase:

```rust
#![feature(specialization)]

pub trait ReflectDrop {
    const REFLECT_DROP : bool = false;
}

impl<T> ReflectDrop for T where T : Clone {}

pub trait PinDropInternal {
    fn is_valid() where Self: ReflectDrop;
}

struct Bears<T>(T);

default impl <T> ReflectDrop for Bears<T> { }

impl <T: Sized> PinDropInternal for Bears<T> {
    fn is_valid() where Self: ReflectDrop {
        let _ = [(); 0 - !!(<Bears<T> as ReflectDrop>::REFLECT_DROP) as usize];
    }
}

fn main() {
}
```

I was mostly fooling around trying to see if there was any way I could get rustc to believe that it would always know whether Bears<T> was Drop regardless of T; for the test case, I changed it to Clone and got rid of actually setting the constant to true in the default case, as well as some unsafe keywords, to avoid muddying the waters with Drop's semantics.  Note that the array trick for turning a constant into a compile time error comes from https://github.com/nvzqz/static-assertions-rs, so it's not as contrived as it initially appears.

Stacktrace:

note: the compiler unexpectedly panicked. this is a bug.

note: we would appreciate a bug report: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#bug-reports

note: rustc 1.27.0-nightly (8a37c75a3 2018-05-02) running on x86_64-apple-darwin
